awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Parameterization of the Land-Surface Thermal and Moisture Heterogeneities
awd_abstract_narration:
This study seeks to create new fundamental knowledge and computer model representations for atmospheric simulations in regions where the land presents large thermal and moisture differences.  The investigators will first conduct a high-resolution field experiment using transformative measurement techniques over the playa in Utah's West Desert, where the terrain is characterized by a relatively uniform rough surface with differences in both space and time of surface temperature and soil-moisture.  Results from this field experiment will be used to: (1) investigate the time/space structure of the surface temperature and moisture fluctuations and (2) formulate new relationships or corrections that account for the differences in surface temperature and moisture.

The research seeks to address the challenges in representing heterogeneities in the Atmospheric Surface Layer (ASL) at finer scales where spatial averaging cannot be used to provide homogeneous fields.  Field data will be collected over the Utah Playa, an area with relatively flat terrain and, presumably, uniform roughness; but variable temperature and soil moisture.  The goal of this study is to run simulations at 100-meter (m) resolution using field data collected under weak stratification to develop new Large Eddy Simulation (LES) parameterizations; with anticipated improvements of 20%.  The main hypothesis being tested is that the spatial structure of temperature and moisture variations will be represented in the detailed flux measurements, even over flat terrain.  Results will be tested in both LES and mesoscale models.  Initial experiments will be conducted for bare, dry soil conditions.  The broader impacts include outreach and education activities with the public; as well as the potential to improve model parameterizations for numerical weather prediction models.

por.por_cntn:
The earth’s surface is composed of a tapestry of highly variable land surfaces that modify winds over many scales. Near the surface, this heterogeneity leads to the interaction of many internal boundary layers that are not in equilibrium and are not well-captured by existing numerical weather models and are poorly described by existing theory. As result, several fundamental outstanding issues still exist in the field of boundary-layer meteorology including surface surface-flux parameterization, energy balance closure, and advection quantification. We hypothesize that heterogeneous surface patches with length-scales of the order of about 10-100 m play an important role in determining the characteristics of unstable and neutral flow structures and ultimately momentum and scalar transport in the atmospheric surface layer. To address this hypothesis and gain improved insight on these surface-layer processes, we conducted a unique field experiment and ran high-resolution simulations.  

We conducted an intensive two-year collaborative field campaign called the Idealized Planar Array experiment for Quantifying Surface heterogeneity or IPAQS at an idealized site characterized by uniform surface roughness but with varying surface temperature and moisture heterogeneities covering a range of scales.  Intensive observations were conducted during the summers of 2018 and 2019 over the Great Salt Lake Desert playa in western Utah at the U.S. Army Dugway Proving Ground’s Surface Layer Turbulence and Environmental Test (SLTEST).  The experiment was designed to capture turbulence processes over a range of scales as well as document the background meteorology. Hence, an array of temporally-synchronized instruments were deployed at 2-m height on a 1 km grid with 200-m spacing along with an embedded high-resolution 10-m tower array. The goal of this synchronized array was to provide temporal snapshots of temperature and velocity fields at resolutions similar to and greater than typical state of the art numerical simulations. These data allow instantaneous and averaged fields to be interrogated (elucidating information on advection, spatial structures, dispersive fluxes, etc.) that have rarely been measured in the field. In addition to these turbulence measurements the array was supplemented with weather stations, an energy balance station, thermal imagery, a distributed temperature sensing (DTS) system, and a 30-meter turbulence tower. A very-small scale turbulence measurement technology was tested using Nano-Scale Thermal Anemometry Probes (NSTAP), while larger scales and structures were measured with Doppler lidar. 

We conducted idealized high-resolution large-eddy simulations of convective boundary layers over ground patches having different temperatures and sizes to help guide theoretical advancements and the field experiments. The simulations showed the clear existence of persistent mean structures within the turbulent flow and their impact on dispersive fluxes arise from these structures.  The simulations showed that thermal dispersive fluxes, which account for persistent-in-time advection fluxes generated by unresolved spatial heterogeneities, provide a quantification of the interaction between surface thermal heterogeneities and the atmospheric boundary-layer mean flow. The simulations led to a new non-dimensional parameter called the heterogeneity parameter that can be used to identify the flow conditions and surface configurations in which heterogeneity effects become important.  

Our collaborative experiments and simulations have been integrated and have led to the following outcomes: 1) unique datasets that are available for the community to use; 2) new experimental methodologies and instruments for probing the atmospheric surface layer over a range of scales; 3) quantification of the spatial heterogeneity of surface fluxes over idealized terrain and the mechanisms (such as persistent mean flow structures) controlling transport in the surface layer; 4) improved closure of the surface energy balance; 5) a new scaling theory that can be used to develop weather-model parameterizations that account for sub-grid scale spatial heterogeneity of surface temperature distributions. Details of these outcomes have been published in peer-reviewed journal articles.
